prompt: How can I add a live translation service for official meetings?

citation_mappings.claim_text: To add live translation for official meetings, decide first whether you need human interpretation (best for accuracy/legal nuance) or AI captions/translation (cheaper, faster, but riskier). 1) Pick the delivery model Simultaneous interpretation (human): Participants choose an audio language channel. Best for formal/regulated settings. Live translated captions (AI): On-screen translated text (and sometimes transcripts). Good for accessibility and lower-stakes content. Hybrid: Human interpreters for the “official record” + AI captions as a convenience. 2) Use what your meeting platform already supports Zoom: Built-in Language Interpretation lets hosts assign interpreters and run interpretation channels in scheduled meetings/webinars. Zoom

Microsoft Teams: Supports multilingual features like live translated captions/transcripts, and newer “Interpreter” capabilities depending on licensing (often Teams Premium / Microsoft 365 Copilot). Microsoft Support+1

If you’re already standardized on Zoom/Teams, starting with the native feature is usually the fastest path. 3) When you need “enterprise/official” reliability, add an RSI provider For higher control (interpreter management, analytics, dial-in, hybrid AV integration, compliance options), consider a Remote Simultaneous Interpretation (RSI) vendor that can plug into your platform: Interprefy (RSI; integrates with common meeting platforms; also available for Teams). Interprefy+1
KUDO (human or AI speech translation; can integrate via widget / run on its own). KUDO+1
